title: COVID-19 Anxiety Trends Analysis
text: covidanxietytrends package provides set functions processing, analyzing, visualizing correlations COVID-19 public health metrics Anxiety-related Google search trends. guide show using package complete analysis workflow, including data cleaning, visualization, feature analysis, model preparation.

what: R package for COVID-19 and anxiety trends correlation analysis:
title: Analyze Correlations Between COVID-19 Metrics and Anxiety Search Trends
text: covidanxietytrends R package provides tools analyze relationships COVID-19 public health metrics (hospitalizations, vaccinations) anxiety-related Google search trends. includes functions data cleaning, visualization, feature selection, statistical modeling. Originally designed Google COVID-19 Open Data vaccination dataset, modular design allows extension pandemic-related datasets.

title: Analyze Correlations Between COVID-19 Metrics and Anxiety Search Trends
text: Install development version GitHub: Dependency package devtools required use install_github(). Please use install.packages("devtools") first install devtools library, run following code R:

title: Analyze Correlations Between COVID-19 Metrics and Anxiety Search Trends
text: Key features include: clean_covid_data() - Prepares raw COVID-19/anxiety trend data analysis eda_viz() - Generates time-series visualizations anxiety trends vs COVID metrics feature_selection() - Identifies significant pandemic indicators make_final_lm_model() - Builds predictive linear models plot_anxiety_time_series() - Creates publication-ready trend plots functions include error handling automated testing.

title: Analyze Correlations Between COVID-19 Metrics and Anxiety Search Trends
code: library(covidanxietytrends)  # Clean sample data clean_data <- clean_covid_data(covid_df)  # Visualize trends eda_viz(clean_data)  # Select significant features selected <- feature_selection(clean_data)  # Build predictive model model <- make_final_lm_model(clean_data)

title: Analyze Correlations Between COVID-19 Metrics and Anxiety Search Trends
text: package made part curriculum University British Columbia’s Data Science 310 course support project correlation COVID-19 hospitalization rates, vaccine numbers Google search trends key term anxiety. project repository can found usage reference functions within package. package developed based data found Google COVID-19 Open Data.

title: Create results linear regression model with the selected features — make_final_lm_model
text: returns final regression model results

title: Create results linear regression model with the selected features — make_final_lm_model
code: # Create sample data sample_data <- data.frame(   date = as.Date("2020-01-01") + 0:3,   search_trends_anxiety = c(10, 12, 15, 14),   new_persons_vaccinated = c(1000, 1200, 1300, 1100),   new_hospitalized_patients = c(50, 60, 55, 65),   new_confirmed = c(100, 120, 130, 110),   new_intensive_care_patients = c(10, 12, 15, 13) )  # Fit the model model <- make_final_lm_model(sample_data) summary(model) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = search_trends_anxiety ~ new_persons_vaccinated +  #>     new_hospitalized_patients + date, data = df) #>  #> Residuals: #> ALL 4 residuals are 0: no residual degrees of freedom! #>  #> Coefficients: #>                             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) #> (Intercept)               -3.043e+04        NaN     NaN      NaN #> new_persons_vaccinated     7.500e-03        NaN     NaN      NaN #> new_hospitalized_patients -1.167e-01        NaN     NaN      NaN #> date                       1.667e+00        NaN     NaN      NaN #>  #> Residual standard error: NaN on 0 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:      1,	Adjusted R-squared:    NaN  #> F-statistic:   NaN on 3 and 0 DF,  p-value: NA #>

what: predicts the model's R^2 and RMSE and then saves it to a table — model_predictions

title: predicts the model's R^2 and RMSE and then saves it to a table — model_predictions
predicts the model's R^2 and RMSE and then saves it to a table — model_predictions
text: final_model lm model test_df test split data verifying . date numeric value output_file Path save output

title: predicts the model's R^2 and RMSE and then saves it to a table — model_predictions
text: returns table R^2 RMSE values

title: predicts the model's R^2 and RMSE and then saves it to a table — model_predictions
code: # Create sample training and test data train_data <- data.frame(   date = as.numeric(as.Date("2020-01-01") + 0:3),   search_trends_anxiety = c(10, 12, 15, 14),   new_persons_vaccinated = c(1000, 1200, 1300, 1100),   new_hospitalized_patients = c(50, 60, 55, 65),   new_confirmed = c(100, 120, 130, 110),   new_intensive_care_patients = c(10, 12, 15, 13) ) test_data <- data.frame(   date = as.numeric(as.Date("2020-01-05") + 0:1),   search_trends_anxiety = c(16, 18),   new_persons_vaccinated = c(1400, 1500),   new_hospitalized_patients = c(70, 75),   new_confirmed = c(140, 150),   new_intensive_care_patients = c(14, 16) )  # Fit a model model <- lm(search_trends_anxiety ~ new_persons_vaccinated + new_hospitalized_patients + date,             data = train_data)  # Compute metrics metrics <- model_predictions(model, test_data, tempfile(fileext = ".csv")) print(metrics) #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   RMSPE R_square #>   <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1  1.25        1  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Save metrics to a file model_predictions(model, test_data, "model_metrics.csv") } # }

text: create regression coefficent table writes csv resulte folder well.

title: create the regression coefficent table and writes it to a csv in the resulte folder as well. — results_lm_coef
create the regression coefficent table and writes it to a csv in the resulte folder as well. — results_lm_coef
text: lm_model lm model output_file Path save output

title: create the regression coefficent table and writes it to a csv in the resulte folder as well. — results_lm_coef
text: returns lm coefficients csv data saved onto

title: create the regression coefficent table and writes it to a csv in the resulte folder as well. — results_lm_coef
code: # Create sample data and fit a model sample_data <- data.frame(   date = as.Date("2020-01-01") + 0:3,   search_trends_anxiety = c(10, 12, 15, 14),   new_persons_vaccinated = c(1000, 1200, 1300, 1100),   new_hospitalized_patients = c(50, 60, 55, 65) ) model <- lm(search_trends_anxiety ~ new_persons_vaccinated + new_hospitalized_patients + date,             data = sample_data)  # Extract coefficients coef_table <- results_lm_coef(model, tempfile(fileext = ".csv")) print(coef_table) #> # A tibble: 4 × 5 #>   term                         estimate std.error statistic p.value #>   <chr>                           <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1 (Intercept)               -30428.           NaN       NaN     NaN #> 2 new_persons_vaccinated         0.0075       NaN       NaN     NaN #> 3 new_hospitalized_patients     -0.117        NaN       NaN     NaN #> 4 date                           1.67         NaN       NaN     NaN  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Save coefficients to a file results_lm_coef(model, "lm_coefficients.csv") } # }

code: # Create sample raw and processed data raw_data <- data.frame(   date = as.Date("2020-01-01") + 0:2,   search_trends_anxiety = c(10, NA, 20),   new_confirmed = c(100, 120, NA) ) processed_data <- data.frame(   date = as.Date("2020-01-01") + 0:1,   search_trends_anxiety = c(10, 15),   new_confirmed = c(100, 120) )

title: Compute Summary Statistic for Numeric Columns — summarize_numeric
code: # data <- data.frame(a = c(1,2,3), b = c(4,5,6)) # summarize_numeric(data) # Create sample data sample_data <- data.frame(   search_trends_anxiety = c(10, 12, 15),   new_confirmed = c(100, 120, 130),   non_numeric = c("a", "b", "c") )  # Summarize numeric columns summary_stats <- summarize_numeric(sample_data) print(summary_stats) #> # A tibble: 2 × 7 #>   Variable                Min   Q25  Mean Median   Q75   Max #>   <chr>                 <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 search_trends_anxiety    10    11  12.3     12  13.5    15 #> 2 new_confirmed           100   110 117.     120 125     130
